Award.AbstractNarration:
FODAVA-Lead: Dimension Reduction and Data Reduction: Foundations for Visualization

The FODAVA (Foundations of Data Analysis and Visualization) Lead research team at the Georgia Institute of Technology provides unified expertise in the critical areas for providing leadership of the FODAVA effort, including machine learning and computational statistics, information visualization, massive-dataset algorithms and data structures, and optimization theory. The team is focused on the fundamental theory and approaches to make breakthroughs in data representations and transformations. The work is directed along the two main axes of scale reduction, data reduction and dimension reduction, to allow human analysts to absorb and penetrate modern large-scale high-dimensional datasets cognitively and visually.

In the area of dimension reduction, the team is extending the theory of automatic feature selection by sparse recovery, developing effective methods for manifold dimension reduction in terms of differential operators, developing new scalable manifold methods using convex-concave saddle-point approaches, and creating dimension reduction methods which incorporate constraints that increase their understandability, such as preserving the data's cluster structure. In the area of data reduction, the team is developing multi-resolution data approximation schemes using hierarchical data structures and multipole-like expansions, approaches for analyzing data of heterogeneous data quality using convolution kernel approaches, and approaches for automatic anomaly cleaning and detection using Lp estimation. The results of this research impact the theory and practice of data analysis, as well as that of information visualization, in particular through the Visual Analytics Digital Library, integration of the resulting methodologies into existing visual analytics systems, and a series of workshops. Undergraduates, under-represented groups, and graduate students are educated in this new interdisciplinary area respectively through Georgia Tech's Threads model, FACES effort, and innovative PhD introductory course emphasizing cross-disciplinary research and new PhD program in Computational Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The FODAVA-Lead project has established new directions for collaborative research and led in the establishment of a large-scale effort to discover and develop the fundamental underpinnings of Data and Visual Analytics. Under the FODAVA-lead leadership, seventeen FODAVA-partner institutions collaborated with the goal of creating and advancing foundations for Data and Visual Analytics. The FODAVA-lead have made fundamental contributions unifying expertise in the critical areas for providing leadership of the FODAVA effort, including machine learning and computational statistics, information visualization, real-time and scalable algorithms and data structures, and optimization theory. 

 

Intellectual Merit: The team has been focused on the fundamental theory and approaches to make breakthroughs in data representations and transformations, and build effective and efficient visual analytics tools that allow human analysts to absorb and penetrate modern data sets cognitively and visually, which present challenges due to their large-scale, high-dimensional, disparate, heterogeneous, and complex nature. The project also has played as a major magnet for researchers in application domains  for utilizing state-of-the-art computational machine learning, data analytics, and visual analytics methods and tools to areas such as health analytics, materials informatics, sustainability, cyber and information security, and other numerous multidisciplinary collaborations. It established impactful interdisciplinary areas with highly collaborative activities and foundational contributions. In particular, FODAVA-lead team has lead in new mathematical modeling and lower dimensional representation of large scale data analytics problems via constrained low rank approximation of matrices and tensors, scalable numerical algorithm development for fast real-time visual interactions, fusion of heterogeneous data sets that facilitates visualization of disparate data sets on one map and comparisons among them. These have had significant impacts in the topic areas such as clustering, classification, text analysis, graph analysis, topic modeling, and recommendation systems.

 

Broader Impacts: This initiative has resulted in numerous benefits for society at large as it has broad applicability and enables solution of important problems of societal importance such as healthcare, bioinformatics, computational finance, biometrics, geospatial systems, and cyber-security, social network, web and text analysis, to name a few. An important spin-off from the project’s numerous activities has been the establishment of new educational programs, which are propagating the accumulated knowledge gained to future generations. For example, Georgia Tech has created multiple new graduate courses in the related areas including a course called Data and Visual Analytics that has become an integral part of the Computational Science and Engineering MS and PhD programs. A new MS program in Data Analytics has been created and attracted a large number of applicants. The team has also organized numerous workshops and symposiums at some of the major conferences in the fields such as IEEE Vis, SIAM Data Mining, and ACM SIGKDD broadening the community significantly.

 

In summary, FODAVA-lead project has made many fundamental research contributions and has shaped the Data and Visual Analytics field. Their contributions will have lasting, long-term impacts in many science and engineering, social, and medical disciplines and future workforce creation.
